biogHist.abstract: The Alliance for Forgotten Australians (AFA) was established in 2006 in response to the 'Forgotten Australians' report. It is a national group of organisations and individuals from across Australia that promotes the interests of the estimated 500,000 people who experienced institutional or other out-of-home care as children in the last century and who suffered physical, emotional and/or sexual abuse: the Forgotten Australians.
biogHist.p: Laurie Humphreys was a founding member of the Alliance for Forgotten Australians and the inaugural Chairman of FACT (Forgotten Australians Coming Together), formed in 2009 in WA.

Humphreys had been involved in advocacy work for former child migrants and Forgotten Australians since the early 2000s, when he made submissions to inquiries being conducted by the British House of Commons and the Australian Senate. Laurie was born in England on 4 July 1933 and entered an orphanage as a 4 year old. At the age of 14, in August 1947, he left England for Australia as a child migrant and spent 3 years at Bindoon in WA. Humphreys died in May 2012.

descriptiveNote.p: Laurie Humphreys was the inaugural Chairman of FACT (Forgotten Australians Coming Together) and a founding member of the Alliance for Forgotten Australians, formed in 2006.

descriptiveNote.p: Joanna Penglase discusses the setting up of the Alliance for Forgotten Australians.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Redress WA, State of Western Australia (2008 - 2011)

descriptiveNote.p: The Alliance for Forgotten Australians (AFA) advocated for improved payments and services to Redress WA applicants and all those who had been in 'care' as children in WA.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Breach of Trust by WA Government

archref.unittitle: Breach of Trust by WA Government
archref.abstract: The Alliance for Forgotten Australians (AFA) a peak body for those who were in 'care' as children, issued a media release in response to the WA State Government's decision to reduce the maximum payment to Redress WA applicants from $80,000 to $45,000. 'The fact that more children were abused and have come forward than the former Government estimated is a cause for horror and sorrow,' said AFA and 'called on the WA Government to face the consequences of Government failures to care for children and to commit the funds that are needed to care for them as adults.'
A Chip off What Block? is the title of a book by former child migrant, Laurie Humphreys. This is a photo of the cover page, showing Laurie on one of his many trips overseas.
